April 2, 2007

Director, Regulatory Management Division
U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services
Department of Homeland Security
111 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, 3rd Floor
Washington, DC 20529

Re: DHS Docket No. USCIS-2006-0044

Dear Director:

On behalf of the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now (ACORN),
I write to express my opposition to the United States Citizenship and
Immigration Services? (USCIS) proposed rule that would significantly increase
fees for naturalization and immigration applications.

ACORN, the nation?s largest community organization of low- and moderate-income
families, has approximately 300,000 members organized into neighborhood chapters
in more than 110 cities across the country. Since 1970, ACORN has advocated and
organized around economic and social justice issues, including those that affect
hundreds of our immigrant members and their families. Recently, our members
have submitted hundreds of comments to USCIS expressing their concerns with the
agency?s proposal, especially for those immigrants who will soon be eligible to
become citizens and will face prohibitive fees to naturalize. Our comments
focus on the potential impact the agency?s proposed fee structure would have on
low-income immigrants and outlines recommendations we encourage USCIS to consider.

Agency?s proposed rule adversely affects low-income immigrants

As a nation of immigrants, we should be making it easier for qualifying
immigrants to become Americans, not harder ? especially if they have played by
the rules and have taken all the proper steps needed to become lawful U.S.
citizens. The fee increases proposed by USCIS are prohibitive for many working
families. Under the current proposal, an application for permanent residency
would increase from $325 to $905 ?nearly a 300% increase. In addition, a
citizenship application (N-400) would virtually double to $595, and fees for
fingerprinting would increase 14%. For example, a family of four would have to
pay approximately $2,430 in application and processing fees to become legal
citizens of the U.S. This is in addition to the English and civics classes many
immigrants need to take in order to prepare for their naturalization exams.

Moreover, USCIS has chronically delayed the processing of naturalization
applications. The backlog of naturalization applications is a serious problem
throughout the country. In its report, Atrapado! Caught in the Backlog:
Immigrant New Yorkers? Endless Wait for Citizenship, New York ACORN concludes
that the backlog has been most severe in New York where, according to USCIS,
more than 126,000 cases remain pending, almost one-fifth of the total number of
outstanding cases nationwide. Although it serves more immigrants than any other
USCIS District Office in the country, the New York City District Office has one
of the longest processing times of any USCIS subdivision.

The situation in New York demonstrates the barriers faced by immigrants hoping
to become citizens, many of whom have already faced many hurdles before they
enter the naturalization process. The growing numbers of immigrants, combined
with increasing complexities of immigration law and the large backlog at USCIS,
have fueled demand for immigration-related legal assistance in many cities.
Shortages in affordable immigration legal services lead many potential citizens
to become prime targets for unscrupulous immigration consultants who defraud
desperate immigrants with promises of an expedited application process.
Immigration assistance fraud is a growing problem that costs immigrant
communities millions of dollars a year and causes untold damage to its victims.

But even those permanent residents who have been able to avoid victimization,
must still face the obstacle of the backlog before achieving the dream of
naturalization. Even years after they have fulfilled the requirements of
citizenship, thousands of immigrants are kept waiting, deprived of numerous
benefits and rights that citizens take for granted. Not surprisingly, under the
proposed fee structure, the long processing time created by an ever-increasing
backlog is only expected to shorten by 20%. Applicants will be forced to pay
more for services that, by USCIS own admission, are already lacking to begin with.

Recommendations

Below are recommendations we hope USCIS will consider as it revises its fee
structure:

?Maintain fee waiver for low-income immigrants. USCIS should continue to
provide fee waivers for those immigrants who would face economic hardship as a
result of paying high immigration adjudication fees. The U.S. should not
discourage hard-working, low-income immigrants from completing the
naturalization process. While USCIS has argued that fee waivers transfer the
cost to other fee-paying applicants, it has failed to recognize how high
naturalization fees price out qualifying immigrants. In fact, high costs for
naturalization may be one factor that discourages immigrants from naturalizing
at the same rates as higher-income immigrants. Without relief for potential
citizens, the proposed fee structure, if adopted, would have discriminatory
results by effectively denying citizenship to the working poor that make up a
large segment of the immigrant population. Immigrants who are eligible and have
played by the rules should not face excessive economic barriers to the American
Dream.

?Request appropriated funds for the adjudication of N-400s. Rather than
raising naturalization fees for the sixth time since 1988, we urge you to call
on Congress to provide sufficient appropriated funds to ensure that citizenship
remains an attainable goal for current and future immigrants. With the help of
appropriated funds, USCIS can make the proper changes needed to bring
immigration services into the modern era without preventing eligible immigrants
from obtaining U.S. citizenship.

Coupled with recent increases in funding for both interior and border
enforcement, including money for the extension of a border wall, the proposal to
swell processing fees to exorbitant levels only reinforces the message that
immigrants are increasingly unwelcome in this country. To change this
perception, USCIS cannot continue to operate 99% on user fees. This system is
not only unfair because it passes on the department?s costs onto the already
struggling immigrants who are trying to become citizens, but it is unsustainable
over the long term.

Therefore, ACORN urges USCIS to abandon its efforts to drastically increase
naturalization
and immigration application fees. At a minimum, USCIS should request, and
Congress should provide, a consistent funding stream to adjudicate N-400
applications. We cannot extol the merits of U.S. citizenship and assimilation
into U.S. society and simultaneously erect a second wall that places the dream
of acquiring U.S. citizenship beyond the reach of countless immigrants who
contribute to this country every day. Only with additional funding can USCIS
process N-400 applications more efficiently and cost-effectively.

I appreciate the opportunity to comment on USCIS? proposed rule to revise the
fee structure for immigration and naturalization applications. Should you have
any questions, please do not hesitate to contact Brenda Mu?iz, ACORN?s
Legislative Director, at (202) 547-2500 or via email: legdirect@acorn.org.

Sincerely,

Maude Hurd
ACORN National President
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Maude Hurd
